thread.title: BoE flags risks from China, market volatility
thread.title_full: BoE flags risks from China, market volatility | Business Spectator

author: Dow Jones newswires
title: BoE flags risks from China, market volatility
text:
The Bank of England said on Friday the risks to the stability of the financial system have intensified since the summer, highlighting a recent slowdown in China and volatility in financial markets as potential vulnerabilities.
The BOE's Financial Policy Committee, which monitors threats to the financial system, on Friday published its latest quarterly assessment of the risks facing banks and other financial firms after several months of market turmoil, particularly in emerging markets.
The panel made no new adjustments to UK bank capital requirements or other recommendations to regulators, but did set out a list of its concerns.
"Overall, the FPC judges that the outlook remains challenging. While the resilience of the financial system has continued to improve, downside risks have risen," the committee said.
The panel, chaired by BOE Governor Mark Carney, said investors have pulled $US90 billion from China and other emerging markets in the past year amid concerns about those regions' economic outlook and the prospect of an interest rate rise in the US
The committee said upcoming stress tests for the UK banking system will determine how vulnerable lenders are to the risks emanating from overseas. Banks have loans and other claims on emerging markets equivalent to three and a half times their equity, and asset managers are also materially exposed, the BOE said.
The FPC also flagged concerns, shared by the Federal Reserve and other regulators, about recent episodes of volatility in financial markets caused by a shortage of liquidity, when investors find it difficult to easily buy or sell assets.
To date, these episodes have been short-lived and haven't undermined overall financial stability, the panel said. But it warned "heightened volatility and reductions in market depth could have more widespread and persistent effects." Officials said they are particularly concerned that a more severe disruption could hit lending to households and businesses.
The FPC asked staff and regulators to prepare a fuller report on market functioning for its next meeting in December.
The committee added Friday that it doesn't see any reason to suspend a flagship government initiative to help first-time buyers onto the housing ladder. The UK treasury had asked the BOE to review its Help-to-Buy program once a year to determine whether it was fuelling a bubble in prices and needed to be scaled back.
